title: How to Make Healthy Muffins

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 350°F (175°C).
steps.description: Lightly grease a muffin pan, or line it with paper muffin liners instead.

steps.headline: Pulse 1½ cups (150 grams) of old-fashioned oats in a food processor.
steps.description: Keep blending the oatmeal until it is finely ground and resembles coarse flour. This will replace the flour typically used in muffin recipes. If you don't own a food processor, you can try using a blender instead. You can also use pre-ground oatmeal instead. Leave the remaining 1 cup (100 grams) of oats wholes and unblended.

steps.headline: Mix together your dry ingredients.
steps.description: Pour the 1½ cups (150 grams) of ground old-fashioned oat into a large bowl, then add the 1 cup (100 grams) of whole oat-fashioned oats. Add in the baking powder, baking soda, salt, and cinnamon. Stir everything together until evenly combined. For more flavorful muffins, add in an extra teaspoon of cinnamon, nutmeg, or pumpkin pie spice. If you are vegan, you will need to use flaxseed eggs. Add another ½ teaspoon of baking powder for extra raising power.

steps.headline: Mash the bananas, then put them into a separate mixing bowl.
steps.description: You can mash them up using a fork or a mixer. Keep mashing them until no lumps or clumps remain. If you don't like bananas, you can use 1 cup (255 grams) of plain, unsweetened applesauce instead.

steps.headline: Stir the eggs, honey, milk, and vanilla extract into the mashed bananas using a whisk.
steps.description: Keep whisking until everything is evenly combined, and there are no lumps or streaks. Be sure to scrape the bottom and sides of the bowl often so that the honey doesn't settle. If you are a strict vegan, try agave nectar instead of honey. If you are vegan, use a non-dairy milk instead of dairy milk. If you are vegan, use 2 flaxseed eggs instead of chicken eggs. Prepare the flax eggs by: Mixing 2 tablespoons (14 grams) of flaxseed meal with 6 tablespoons (90 milliliters) of water. Let it sit for 5 minutes, then stir it into your oil mixture.

steps.headline: Stir the oat mixture into banana mixture.
steps.description: Keep stirring until everything is just mixed together. Don't worry if it looks too wet or lumpy.

steps.headline: Let the batter sit for 10 minutes.
steps.description: During this time, the oats will soak up the moisture from the eggs and milk. Once the 10 minutes are up, you can fold in ½ cup (cc grams) of tasty extras, such as dried fruits or chopped nuts.

steps.headline: Scoop the mixture into a greased or lined muffin tin.
steps.description: You have enough batter to make 14 muffins. Once you have the batter in the muffin tin, you can sprinkle the tops with some old-fashioned oatmeal; press the oats gently into the muffin tops to ensure that they don't fall off.

steps.headline: Bake the muffins in the center rack of the oven for 20 to 23 minutes.
steps.description: They are ready when a toothpick poked into the center comes out clean.

steps.headline: Wait for the muffins to cool before serving them.
steps.description: Allow them cool in the pan for about 10 minutes first. Then, take them out, and let them finish cooling—about 10 to 15 minutes more.

steps.headline: Preheat your oven 425°F (220°C).
steps.description: Lightly grease a muffin pan, or insert of muffin liners.

steps.headline: Mix together the flour, baking powder, cinnamon, baking soda, and salt.
steps.description: Sift the flour into a large mixing bowl, then add the baking powder, cinnamon, baking soda, and salt. Stir everything together with a whisk until evenly combined. If you are vegan, you will need to use flaxseed eggs. Add another ½ teaspoon of baking powder for extra raising power.

steps.headline: Stir in the grated and chopped apple.
steps.description: Grate enough apples to fill 1 cup (120 grams), and add it to the flour mixture. Next, peel, core, and chop enough apples to fill 1 cup (120 grams). Add the apple chunks to the mixture, then stir everything together with a spatula. Having a mixture of grated apple and apple chunks will give you a more consistent texture. Make the apple chunks no bigger than ¼-inch (0.64-centimeters).

steps.headline: Beat together the oil and maple syrup in a separate bowl.
steps.description: If you are using coconut oil, be aware that it may start to turn solid. If this happens, heat the mixture in the microwave for 30 seconds. Make sure that you are using a microwave-safe bowl, however!

steps.headline: Add in the eggs, yogurt, applesauce, and vanilla, whisking well after each item you add.
steps.description: Add the eggs into the oil mixture first, then stir well with a whisk. Add in the yogurt, and beat again. Add in the applesauce, and vanilla, and stir until everything is well-combined and no streaks remain. If you are vegan, use 2 flaxseed eggs instead of chicken eggs. Prepare the flax eggs by: Mixing 2 tablespoons (14 grams) of flaxseed meal with 6 tablespoons (90 milliliters) of water. Let it sit for 5 minutes, then stir it into your oil mixture. If you are vegan, use "vegan buttermilk" instead of yogurt. Mix together ½ cup (120 milliliters) of non-dairy milk and 1½ teaspoons of vinegar. Let the mixture sit for 5 minutes, then add it to your oil mixture.

steps.headline: Gently stir the wet mixture into the dry mixture with a rubber spatula.
steps.description: Keep stirring until everything is just combined. It's okay if there are a few lumps and the batter is thick. If you over-mix the batter, your muffins may turn out tough!

steps.headline: Scoop the batter into the muffin tin.
steps.description: You have enough to make 12 muffins. To ensure that each muffin well gets the same amount, consider using an ice cream scoop to measure out the batter. For extra texture, sprinkle the top of each muffin with some raw sugar.

steps.headline: Bake the muffins on the center rack in the oven for 13 to 13 minutes.
steps.description: They are done when a toothpick poked into the center comes out clean.

steps.headline: Let the muffins cool on a wire rack before serving.
steps.description: Let them cool in the pan for about 10 minutes. Take them out, and let them finish cooling—about 10 to 15 minutes more.

steps.headline: Use plain, unsweetened applesauce instead of butter.
steps.description: Start with using half of the butter your recipe calls for, and substitute applesauce for the rest. The more applesauce/less butter you use, the denser your muffin will be. If you don't mind an extra-dense muffin, then feel free to switch over completely to applesauce. Don't have any applesauce? Try using a plant-based oil, such as canola, corn, sunflower, or extra-virgin olive, instead. Use 25% less oil than you would butter.

steps.headline: Try whole wheat flour instead of all-purpose white flour.
steps.description: Much like with applesauce, the more whole wheat flour you use, the denser your muffin will be. If you are just starting out, try using half white flour and half whole wheat flour. If you use all whole wheat flour, and cut the all-purpose flour entirely, you will need to add 1 to 2 tablespoons of liquid, such as: buttermilk, fruit juice, or vegetable oil. Don't want to use whole wheat flour? Try rolled oats, cornmeal, or buckwheat flour instead!

steps.headline: Use less sugar.
steps.description: You decrease the sugar by however much you want, but keep in mind that the muffins will be very bland if you use no sugar whatsoever. Try starting out with 1 teaspoon of sugar per muffin. This means that, if your recipe yields 12 muffins, you should only use ¼ cup (55 grams) of sugar. Remember, you can always sweeten the muffins back up after baking with a little bit of honey or jam. Cutting the sugar by 25% won't affect the flavor or texture by a noticeable amount. Can't bare to part with the sugar, or want an even healthier option? Try brown sugar or agave nectar instead. You might want to use less brown sugar and agave nectar than the recipe calls for due to the intense flavor. Adding some spices, such as cardamom, ground cinnamon, and vanilla, can work wonders without adding unhealthy sugars and calories.

steps.headline: Add fiber with some fruit.
steps.description: Most health-hacks focus on taking away ingredients, but they rarely focus on adding ingredients. Fresh fruit (as opposed to dried) is a great option because of the fiber! Try adding ½ to 1 cup (50 to 100 grams) of some fresh, chopped fruit to your next muffin recipe. Keep in mind that you may need to bake your muffins longer, however. Don't have any fresh fruit? Try dried fruit or fruit puree instead. Raw vegetables can also add a dose of fiber to muffins, such as zucchini or carrot. Be sure to shred them well in a food processor first, however!

steps.headline: Add protein with nuts.
steps.description: You can use chopped nuts, a spoonful of nut butter, or a splash of nut-based milk. You can even replace 25% of your flour with a nut-based flour instead. You can buy nut flours in specialty supermarkets. If you can't get any, ground your choice of nuts into a fine meal using a food processor. Using nut flours and nut-based milks won't affect the texture too much, but they may give the muffins a slight nutty flavor.

steps.headline: Add some extra egg white for protein.
steps.description: Eggs get a bad rep because of their high cholesterol levels, but they are also full of protein--and are very low on the calories. Folding an extra whipped egg whit or two into your batter will not only give you some more protein, but it will also make the muffins less dense—which can be helpful, especially if you are using applesauce or whole wheat flour.

steps.headline: Don't use full-fat dairy products.
steps.description: Try using low-fat Greek yogurt or low-fat buttermilk instead of whole milk. This will help cut back some saturated fats while helping retain moisture. You can also use soymilk for a vegan option. Using low-fat dairy products won't necessarily lower all of the fats. They will, however, reduce the bad, saturated fats.

steps.headline: Control portion sizes by making smaller muffins.
steps.description: People usually just eat one muffin, be it a small one or a large one. A larger muffin will contain much more fats, calories, and carbohydrates than smaller muffins. If you need to count any of those, consider using a mini or regular muffin pan instead of a jumbo one. If you are using a standard-sized muffin tin, fill the wells half-way instead of the usual two-thirds of the way.
